tasks.task: Farmer educates on alligator waste management for agricultural systems
subtasks: Farmer introduces himself and the Oklahoma Cooperative Extension Service
Clarifies lack of alligator production in Oklahoma but mentions indigenous cultures
Discusses purposes of alligator farms including leather, meat, novelty, and tourism
Explains alligator growth phases and temperature-controlled farming techniques
Compares alligator digestive system to birds, noting high protein feed requirements
Describes two farming systems: closed (self-reproducing) and open (wild egg collection, some release)
Walks through the alligator farm layout and feeding systems, including pit recharge and water spray for heat control
Outlines waste management practices: holding pond and field irrigation with K-line pods
Cites challenges in sizing facilities due to lack of specific data on alligator manure characteristics
Highlights efforts to address odor control through calcium phosphate precipitation and anaerobic digestion
Recognizes the importance of wind direction in waste spreading operations
Acknowledges collaboration with university researchers and extension services

tasks.task: Waste management channel on YouTube exploring agricultural practices
subtasks: Introduces the goal of visually educating farmers about various waste systems
Highlights a 2010 visit to Louisiana to observe Dr. Ron Sheffield's alligator wastewater treatment
Mentions Dr. Sheffield’s passing and the farmer's current role as a national expert on alligator waste
